review.title: Populous: A tool for populating ontology templates
review.abstract: We present Populous, a tool for gathering content with which to populate an ontology. Domain experts need to add content, that is often repetitive in its form, but without having to tackle the underlying ontological representation. Populous presents users with a table based form in which columns are constrained to take values from particular ontologies; the user can select a concept from an ontology via its meaningful label to give a value for a given entity attribute. Populated tables are mapped to patterns that can then be used to automatically generate the ontology's content. Populous's contribution is in the knowledge gathering stage of ontology development. It separates knowledge gathering from the conceptualisation and also separates the user from the standard ontology authoring environments. As a result, Populous can allow knowledge to be gathered in a straight-forward manner that can then be used to do mass production of ontology content.
histories: in Adrian Paschke, Albert Burger begin_of_the_skype_highlighting end_of_the_skype_highlighting, Andrea Splendiani, M. Scott Marshall, Paolo Romano: Proceedings of the 3rd International Workshop on Semantic Web Applications and Tools for the Life Sciences, Berlin,Germany, December 8-10, 2010

sections.heading: 1.1 Previous work
sections.text: Excel2RDF3, Convert2RDF4, and RDF123 [1] are three tools that allow users to generate Resource Description Framework (RDF) patterns from spreadsheets. Although RDF is the reference syntax for the Web Ontology Language (OWL), its serialization is complex and not meant for humans, allowing them to define higher OWL patterns in patterns. However, ExcelImporter Plugin5 for Prote "ge 4.0" was a step away from these tools and allowed users to transform spreadsheets directly into OWL axioms, but it was limited to a small set of OWL constructs. Newer tools to support template data and patterns include Mapping Master [14], OPPL 2, and the Prote "Matrix Plugin6."

sections.heading: 1.2 Requirements
sections.text: All previous tools developed in this area tend to focus on the transformation from template to ontology, offering little or no support for filling and validating the content of the template. Furthermore, tools such as ExcelImporter, OPPL and MappingMaster are integrated into the ontology development tool, so they are aimed at users who are already familiar with ontology development. A table-based tool for ontology authoring should shield the user from the underlying ontology and help him fill the template. Providing validation at the time of authorship should significantly reduce the time taken to debug and process the data collected in the table. Here, we list some key requirements for an ontology-based table editor: 1. Concepts can be described in relation to other concepts from other ontologies. When setting up Populous, users must be able to browse the ontology and the content must be limited to the column.

sections.heading: 2 Populous
sections.text: This year, it is as far as ever in the history of the city, where it is as far as never before.

sections.heading: 2.1 Building an Ontology with Populous
sections.text: The pattern in ontology states that each cell must have a nucleation. We must create a template with two columns, column A is for cell type concepts, while column B is for nucleation concepts. Ontologies that already exist cells and their nucleation, which we can import into Populous. By connecting with BioPortal, we can load cell typontology (CTO) [4] and phenotype and trait ontology (PATO) [8]. To limit column A to terms from the CTO, we highlight all cells in column A and limit them to all subclasses of the root class. Column B is a limited subclass of the nucleation concept from PATO. The template is now ready to be colonized by the domain expert. Figure 2 shows a partially populated template. The terms in green show a valid term has been entered into the automatic cell pattern.

sections.heading: 3 Use case and evaluation
sections.text: The kidney is a complex organ consisting of several different anatomical compartments that together allow the filtration of waste from the blood in the form of urine. Each of the kidney compartments is composed of a variety of cell types, and the specificity of the compartments is based on these specialized cell functions, which together allow the filtration of waste from the blood in the form of urine. [12] describes kidney cells, their function and their anatomical locations. KUPO is built to annotate and integrate a variety of KUP-related data held in the kidney and in the Urinal Pathway Knowledge Base (KUPKB). A simple template was designed for experts from the KUP domain to capture the relationships between cell types, their anatomical location and their biological functions.

sections.heading: 4 Discussion
sections.text: It is not the way in which we fill this niche and meet the requirements outlined in Section 1. The simple tabular user interface is familiar to users who have already used a spreadsheet to lower the entry requirements for domain experts to contribute to the development of ontological development projects. However, the release of Populous is an early version; there are still many possible additions, some of which are: 1. Popular can handle multiple values in a cell that maps to the properties of Populous maps. Extensions to Populous as some small syntax can be used to expand the ability to use OWL's syntax would be useful as they are able to specialize numbers for cardinality and numbers.

This type of pattern is common in ontology development where you have one set of entities being described in terms of another set of entities [17].
Excel2RDF, Convert2RDF and RDF123 [1] are three tools that allow users to generate Resource Description Framework (RDF) statements from spreadsheets.
The more recent tools to support template data and pattern instantiation include Mapping Master [14], OPPL 2 [11,6] and the Protégé Matrix plugin:

MappingMaster moves away from the row centric view of spreadsheets and has an expressive macro language called M [15,14] that can handle non-uniform and complex spreadsheets.
MappingMaster moves away from the row centric view of spreadsheets and has an expressive macro language called M [15,14] that can handle non-uniform and complex spreadsheets.
M combines a macro language for referring to cells in a spreadsheet with a human readable syntax for generating OWL expressions called the Manchester OWL Syntax [10].
– The Ontology Pre-Processing Language (OPPL) [6,11] (version 2) is a scripting language similar to M.
– The Ontology Pre-Processing Language (OPPL) [6,11] (version 2) is a scripting language similar to M.
Populous is an extension of RightField[21]; RightField is for creating Excel documents that contain ontology based restrictions on spreadsheets content.

RightField enables users to upload Excel spreadsheets, along with ontologies from their local file systems, or from the BioPortal [13] (a repository of biological ontologies available at http://bioportal.
By connecting to BioPortal we can load the Cell Type Ontology (CTO) [4] and Phenotype and Trait Ontology (PATO) [8].
By connecting to BioPortal we can load the Cell Type Ontology (CTO) [4] and Phenotype and Trait Ontology (PATO) [8].
The Kidney and Urinary Pathway Ontology (KUPO) [12] describes kidney cells, their function and their anatomical locations.

Populous was used to constrain the allowable values in columns A, C and D to concepts from the Open Biomedical Ontology Cell Type Ontology [4], subclasses or part of the Kidney or Urinary system concepts from the Mouse Adult Gross Anatomy Ontology [9], and all subclasses of the Biological Process concept from the Gene Ontology [20], respectively.
